abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Protected Areas
            Management Project for Tunisia were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to global environment outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: coupling park
            management activities with local partnerships and awareness
            raising programs has a strong positive impact on improving
            community perceptions. The project demonstrated that the
            partnerships with schools, research institutions, media and
            local private sector helped solidify the collaborative
            spirit towards nature conservation objectives in each of the
            regions, improved the understanding and positive perceptions
            of the local people and significantly reduced the number of
            illegal activities. Among the three parks, Jbil proved to be
            more challenging in this aspect given the small number of
            communities, many of which are not settled. In future, a
            dedicated awareness strategy based on the specific
            characteristics of each park is merited. Fostering local
            partnerships for knowledge generation of the existing
            biodiversity in a park enhances its management capacity.
            Rather than mobilizing a large scale technical assistance,
            the Project Management Unit (PMU) has contracted several
            research institutes, science faculties and consultants to
            carry out small-scale analytical works on very specific
            subject matters. This approach showed that a very rich and
            useful information base could be obtained at a lower cost
            than with classical technical assistance, and engages local
            institutions for more sustainable partnership relations. It
            is important to manage expectations about what can be
            achieved in a first phase of a participatory natural
            resources management project. The project required
            significant time and resources to set up the participatory
            planning methodology, with a strong element of learning by
            doing as it went forward. Also, there was a need to bring
            the parks to a level where the minimum infrastructure
            required for receiving increased visitor numbers are in
            place. These are prerequisites to the launch of successful
            eco-tourism activities, which require more sophisticated
            institutional collaboration structures across different
            sectors and can be envisaged in a follow-on phase.

5087806.trustfund:
TF022384-GEF2:TUNISIA CONSERVATION OF
            BIODIVERSITY AND PRTECTED AREAS,TF028357-GEF1-EPPG TUNISIA BIODIVERSITY
            STRATEGY AND ACTION PLAN (BSAP),TF021160-EC METAP-PROTECTION OF COASTAL LAGOONS,TF051308-GEF2 FSP-TUNISIA:PROTECTED
            AREAS MANAGEMENT PROJECT
5087806.majtheme: Trade and integration,Environment and natural resource management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Protected Areas Management Project
            aims at improving the management, and protection of selected
            national parks, with a focus on biodiversity conservation
            for the overall improvement of the local population's
            welfare. For this purpose, the components will: 1) reinforce
            the institutional capacity of the Directorate General of
            Forestry, and the Ministry of Environment, for a sustainable
            protected areas management. Training, technical assistance
            (TA), and scientific studies will support a strong regional
            focus on modules targeting park management personnel, and
            potential partners - nongovernmental organizations (NGOs)
            and the private sector - in a management participatory
            approach; 2) manage and restore unique, and distinct
            ecosystems (wetlands, arid mountains, savanna, and desert)
            in the three national parks (Ichkeul, Bouhedma, and Jbil),
            assist in the development of eco-tourism activities, and,
            establish community development plans, compatible with the
            objectives of sustainable biodiversity conservation.
            Management plans will emphasize on technical aspects -
            inventory, infrastructure, surveillance - and on strategic
            issues, such as participatory reviews, and assessment of
            practices by local communities, in addition to scientific
            monitoring in the sustainable use of natural resources; and,
            3) build public support for biodiversity conservation,
            targeting priority groups, including that of specific
            stakeholders, through delivery mechanisms such as mass
            media, formal and informal education, and, through the
            development of linkages with local NGOs, schools, and other organizations.

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Protected Areas Management
            Project : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Protected Areas Management Project
            aims to improve the management of three national parks:
            Ichkeul, Bouhedma, and Jbil, for the purposes of conserving
            biodiversity of global importance and contributing to the
            overall improvement in welfare of local populations. The
            project's approach to biodiversity conservation is
            based on community participation. The participatory approach
            will be carried out through the coordination with national,
            governorate, and local level institutions. Some of the
            project components may trigger the Bank's policy on
            involuntary resettlement, which also includes specific
            provision for the loss of access to natural resources in
            parks and protected areas. To achieve its objectives of
            biodiversity conservation, the project may require the
            restriction of access to the resources in the defined core
            areas that are currently utilized by the population. The
            Park Management Team (PMT) for each protected area will be
            the main executors of the process framework. During the
            project implementation, when conflicting views concerning
            the utilization of resources arise, the Development
            Committee and PMT will be the forum for dispute resolution.
            If no acceptable solutions can be reached, claims will be
            presented to the Local Development Council. Should conflicts
            still remain, the claims will be settled by the Regional
            Development Council. The execution of the process framework
            will be monitored by the Project Management Unit.
